titleStmt.title: Uppsala University Library, Gr. 21
titleStmt.sponsor: Greek manuscripts in Sweden – a digitization and cataloguing project

publicationStmt.publisher: Manuscripta.se: A Digital Catalogue of Manuscripts in Sweden

msDesc.head: Poetry miscellany, probably for educational use

p.note: One blank leaf (except for the signum Cod. Gr. 21 on ) folded around the spine functions as flyleaves on either side of the bookblock.

watermark.term: Lily in circle; B; G P; M

supportDesc.foliation: Foliation in pencil by a modern hand: 1–30.

p.note: Blank except numbers and former shelfmarks: on a paper slip with the number II. on it; cf. the former shelfmark, n:o 11, on .

binding.p:
Pattern-woven silk cover in gold, green, and beige over paper boards. No endbands. Brokatpapier in green and copper is used for pastedowns. For the identical pattern but in different colours, see Heijbroek (1994)
; pattern N:o 72 (manufacturer Georg Reimund, Augsburg, who was active ).
binding.condition: The spine is badly worn and damaged, the boards now being held together provisionally with the help of a slip of brown paper pasted aroung the spine. The bookblock has come loose completely. A lending slip that used to be pasted to is now unstuck.

history.provenance: The manuscript was acquired by Jacob Jonas Björnståhl (), most probably during his travels through Europe in the years . That it would, as is the case with several of his other manuscripts, have its provenance in one of the Thessalian monasteries, is perhaps less likely given its rather costly binding in silk and brocatpapier.
history.acquisition: Came to Uppsala University Library in as part of the Björnståhl donation.

msItem.title: Opera et dies
msItem.finalRubric: Τέλος τῶν ἔργων καὶ ἡμερῶν Ἡσιόδου· ἀμήν. Δέχου τὸ ῥαψώδημα τοῦ συγγόνου ἥδυσμα καὶ παίδευμα Πέρση σῶν τρόπων.

note.p:
With interlinear glosses and a few longer scholia. Following the main text, there are on also sketches and diagrams relating to it (illustrating e.g. the four elements, agricultural implements, celestial bodies, the zodiac). The sketches may be compared to the illustrations in the Venice print edition from 1537: Trincavelli (1537)
.
is blank. The text continues on the next page without interuption.

msItem.title: A diagram on logical categories
msItem.incipit: Πᾶν πρᾶγμα ἢ διαιρετὸν ἢ ἀδιαίρετον
msItem.explicit: ὡς τῶν μελαίνων, τὰ μὲν ψυχρά, τὰ δὲ τερμά

msItem.title: Commentarius ad Theocriti Syringem
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ σοφωτάτου χαρτοφύλακος τῆς ἁγίας Ἰουστινιανῆς, καὶ πάσης Βουλγαρίας κυρίου Ἰωάννου τοῦ Πεδιασίμου, ἐξήγησις εἰς τὴν τοῦ Θεοκρίτου Σύριγγα

msItem.title: In Theocriti Syringem
Τοῦ σοφωτάτου ῥήτορος τῶν ῥητόρων κύρου Μαξίμου τοῦ Ὁλοβόλου εἰς τὴν Θεοκρίτου Σύριγγα σύνοψις τῶν μέτρων
msItem.incipit: Τὸ ἐπιγραμμάτιον ἡ Σύριγξ ἔστι μὲν ἐννεάφωνος

filiation.note: The manuscript is used for the critical edition.

msItem.title: Commentarius in securim
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ Ὁλοβόλου εἰς τὸν Πέλεκυν ἐξήγησις συνοπτική
msItem.incipit: Ὁ πέλεκυς οὐχ ὡς ὁ Σύριγξ καὶ οἱ Βωμοὶ
msItem.explicit: ὄλβιος καὶ εὐτυχὴς ἀεὶ πνεῖ καὶ ζῇ

msItem.title: A shorter version or paraphrase of the aforementioned commentary
msItem.incipit: Ὁ Ἐπειὸς ὁ Φωκεὺς ὤπασε καὶ παρέσχε δῶρον τὸν πέλεκυν
msItem.explicit: ὃν σὺ ἀμφιδερχθῇς ἵλεως ἐν τῷ θυμῷ καὶ ἐν τῇ ψυχῇ, τὸν καὶ τοῦτον, πνέει ἀεὶ ὄλβιος

filiation.note: Strodel characterizes these manuscripts as possibly directly related (Handschrift S 43, die möglicherweise ebenfalls direkt auf F zurückgeht).

msItem.title: Syrinx
msItem.note: With interlinear glosses. The poem is written as a carmen figuratum in the approximate shape of a flute, and includes a frame, a bell at the top end, and eighteen tone holes set in the middle of the pipes.

msItem.title: A paraphrase of Theocritus’ Syrinx
msItem.incipit: Ὦ Σύριγξ, σὺ μὲν ἔχεις ὄνομα σύριγγος
msItem.explicit: τῇ Καλλιόπᾳ, τῆ νηλεύστῳ, ἀντὶ τοῦ ἕνεκα τῆς κόρης τῆς ἐλλόπιδος, τῆς καλλιφώνου καὶ ἀλιθεύστου

msItem.title: Ara
msItem.note: With interlinear glosses in the Manuel Holobolus tradition. The poem is written as a carmen figuratum in the shape of an altar with a base and dome.

msItem.title: Two commentaries to the aforementioned Altar of Dosiadas

msItem.incipit: Ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ βωμός, ὃν ἔτευξε τῆς ἀνδρώας τῆς γυναικός
msItem.explicit: ὑπὸ τοῦ Ἡρακλέους καὶ ὑπὸ τῶν Ἑλλήνων

msItem.incipit: Ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ βωμός, ὅντινα ἐμὲ τεῦξεν ὁ μέροψ
msItem.explicit: ἐν ἀμφικλύστῳ καὶ ἐν τῇ περικλύστῳ λίμνῃ
msItem.note: In the lower left margin the scribe has added an alternative altar shape with reference to the teacher’s exemplar (οὕτως εἶχε ἐσχηματισμένος ἐν τῷ τοῦ διδασκάλου).

msItem.title: Carmen aureum
msItem.note: With interlinear glosses and commentary. The main text and accompanying paraphrase are connected with the help of reading signs. The rubricized title of the paraphrase, which is given in code, would in plain read Πυθαγορικῶν χρυσέων ἐπῶν φράσις.

msItem.title: A grammatical treatise
msItem.incipit: Σημείωσαι ὅτι ὁ βουλόμενος συντάξαι ὀρθῶς
msItem.explicit: Τρίτον δὲ εἰς δοτικήν, οἷον, ἐγὼ δίδωμί σοι

watermark.ref:
Harlfinger Chapeau 51
Venice
Bartolomeo Zanetti’s scriptorium.

p.note: This paper of coarser quality was only used for one substitute bifolium. No watermarks visible.

collation.formula: Q1(VI-1post f.7+2f.8–9)f.13 + Q2IVf.21 + Q3(II-1post f.24)f.24 + Q4IIf.28 + Q5If.30
collation.p: No threads are visible in the quires due to the excessive use of adhesive at the spine. The collation is thus tentative and based on the different kinds of paper and the watermark positions.

layout.note: Layout and number of lines varying.
Main text always 24 lines per page. In the commentary surrounding the main text there are around twice as many lines per page.

handDesc.handNote:
Nikolaos Gaitanos Marulos Responsible for all the main texts, and most of the paratexts including rubricized parts, commentaries and glossae. He uses an even, slightly right-sloping humanist minuscule in the style of Camillus Venetus (so-called Camillus-Schrift); cf. Harlfinger (1977)
.

A sixteenth-century minuscule hand, probably responsible for the Syrinx paraphrase, the second paraphrase to the Altar (i.e. the one to the left on ), as well as the note in the lower margin on the same page. Note the use of the Fähnchen-Tau, in conformity with the main scribe.
Scattered glosses in a cursive minuscule hand, mainly in the outermost margin and occasionally in-between lines.

decoDesc.p: Rubrics and initials in red ink on and . On , , and larger decorated initials (6–7 lines high) and a headpiece with a vegetal pattern consisting of convolute hairlines, buds and curlicues. Similar but smaller decoration and initial on . Red ink is also used profusely for comments and interlinear glosses.
Pen-drawn illustrations and a diagram on .

history.origin: Probably written in Venice in the 1540s. Watermarks and the handwriting (in so-called Camillus-Schrift style) may suggest a link to the workshop of Bartolomeo Zanetti. Its present binding stems from the mid-eighteenth century.
